Award.AwardTitle: Econometric Tools for Analysis of Derivatives Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops new statistical techniques for extracting real-time economic information from the prices of derivatives securities. The basic idea is that option prices include information about market conditions, the general pricing of risk, and the specific risk of a crash. The new method will be valuable to a wide audience, ranging from researchers to policy makers and regulators interested in the real time assessment of market and economic conditions, including the probability and pricing of 'tail' events. The work advances science in these fields and also promotes the national prosperity by providing new techniques for gathering information useful to businesses and policymakers from existing data.

The team develops new inference techniques to ensure satisfactory performance based on a parametric model for option prices with minimal restrictions on the dynamics driving the underlying asset prices. The estimated system embeds valuable information about market conditions, the pricing of risk in general and crash risk in particular. The team will apply these methods to predicting future equity returns, extracting spot volatility, pricing volatility risk and volatility derivatives, and documenting global linkages in market 'fears'. Formal inference and specification testing for option pricing is difficult. Complications arise from latent and persistent state variables, no-arbitrage constraints, nonlinear pricing, unbalanced panels, sizeable measurement errors and time-varying risk premiums. The PIs develop procedures inspired by methods for nonparametric volatility estimation from high-frequency time series data. The extension to a parametric cross-sectional setting provides the tools for model evaluation, and they will obtain joint asymptotic distributional results for high frequency and option implied volatility estimators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provides new tools for extraction of real-time economic information from option markets based on a rigorous scientific methodology. The main objective is to learn about current market conditions, the price or compensation for exposure to financial market risk in general, and downside crash risk in particular. Such information is of great interest to policy makers, regulators, exchanges, and investors, who use it as an input for their economic and financial decision making.

Options are derivatives securities whose prices reflect both the expectations about the future returns on an underlying asset and the expected compensation, or risk premium, that investors require to accept the risk associated with holding that asset. The challenge is to separately identify the two components to obtain, one, an objective measure of the expectations regarding the future asset return distribution and, two, the size of the associated risk premium. The latter is of particular interest to economists seeking to understand the variation over time in the compensation for financial risk.

Our empirical results show that the risk premium associated with downside tail events is particularly informative regarding investors’ appetite for exposure to the broader equity market. We obtain this result through an option-implied tail risk measure constructed from either a flexible parametric model or from a model-free, or nonparametric, approach. For the U.S. stock market, we document that our parametric option-implied tail measure provides predictive power for the equity market returns over the coming 3-12 months. In a separate study, we find a similar predictive relation in all European countries, for which we can obtain good quality option data. That is, their local option-implied tail measures predict the future European equity market returns in local currency at horizon of 3 to 12 months. Turning to our nonparametric measure, we likewise find that this U.S. tail measure has forecast power for the Japanese stock market returns, when converted into U.S. dollars. However, contrary to the prior results, this does not hold, if the Japanese option-implied tail measure is used to predict the yen-denominated Japanese returns. We conjecture this finding may be rationalized by the fact that – in contrast to other developed markets -- the trading in all major financial markets in Japan is dominated by foreign accounts. It is consequently natural that the perception and compensation for risk, ultimately, is determined from a foreign perspective. The last observation provides a partial answer to the conundrum in the literature over why Japanese financial markets seem to defy the usual empirical regularities for other developed markets across the globe.

The above-mentioned results are derived from our new inference techniques using all available options on a given day through a flexible parametric model or, alternatively, if a sufficient number of short-dated options are available, through our model-free approach. The latter only relies on a subset of options that are particularly informative of investors’ attitude towards tail or crash events. In either case, we obtain a daily measure that can be extracted with better precision, and assessed more rigorously, than possible with pre-existing procedures. In particular, we stress the advantages afforded by combining our techniques with a deliberate reliance on short-dated options. The trading of the latter securities is now very liquidly due to the expansion in issuance of so-called weekly options. Hence, we expect our techniques to serve as a basis for many related studies going forward.

One example of such an analysis, exploiting the advantage of short-dated options, is a different study included under our grant. It shows that we can separate the expectation regarding tail events into an anticipated frequency of adverse negative jump events and their associated (jump) size distribution. Existing tractable option pricing models employ techniques requiring the jump size distribution to remain constant over time. We find this assumption to be counterfactual. There are distinct periods associated with significant movements both in the intensity of jumps and expected size of the jumps. This opens the door for many new applications, while also posing challenges for the option pricing literature at large.

We finally point to interesting areas for future work. Our techniques can readily be applied for other asset classes, including individual stocks, foreign exchange, commodities, and fixed income securities, like bonds and treasury bills. It is also straightforward to exploit option data for intraday analysis of shifts in risk pricing, for example around macroeconomic or firm-specific news announcements or during particularly turbulent times. This can help us understand the price discovery process, monitor the impact of policy or governance changes, and assess evolving market risks in real time.

We have made our nonparametric tail index series for many different indices and countries available on the website: tailindex.com. It explains the methodology, displays the series, provides computer code, and allows for direct downloading of the daily index series in different file formats.
